ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We only had live virtual lectures, five times a week for 50 minutes each.
na
oral presentation through voice thread

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to speak, read, and understand basic Korean. I now can understand basic conversations and give directions and express myself in basic ways.
Basic Korean vocabulary and grammar. Able to uphold simple conversations as well as write about events or situations.
speaking basic Korean, basic Korean grammar and vocab, understanding toward Korean culture
I developed a basic level of understanding of Korean and gained insight into Korean culture through student-led presentations.
Building blocks of reading, listening, speaking, and writing. Great introductory course.
I learned lots of basic Korean vocabulary, sentence structures, and grammar.
I learned a lot about the basics of Korean and a bit about Korean culture.
An introductory survey to Korean. The syllabus accurately states what I learned.
I learned how to read Korean and possibly write some words as well. I now have a grasp of basic Korean grammar which I think will be helpful for continuing to learn Korean.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved the pacing of this course. It never felt like too much work, and I never felt overwhelmed by the amount of information I was learning in class. I think the same format can be kept for following years.

Strength: Great introduction to korean and very interactive with frequent break out rooms to practice speaking. Fun projects thrown in as well. Reasonable amount of work, but it relies on how much effort you put in. 

Weakness: Because of virtual format, there was very little in class writing practice.

strength: the teacher is very encouraging, effective, and caring
weakness: I expected to learn more grammar structures, but I guess it's the problem of the textbook

Strengths: The course is fast-paced so a lot is learned in a relatively short amount of time.  However, homework and listening exercises never feel like strictly busywork, every exercise serves a purpose to reinforce vocab or grammar learned in the lessons and helps improve understanding in a meaningful way.  Partner work in class helps to learn the material in a casual, low-stress way, while at the same time help from the professor is readily available.
Weaknesses: I can't think of any.

I think this course was super helpful in providing a good foundation for the Korean Language. I enjoyed the structure of having class Monday through Friday and found many opportunities to practice the language outside and during class. I also enjoyed the use of breakout rooms to practice with classmates and the availability of the teacher to answer questions during these sessions.

Strengths: Very dedicated teaching staff and plenty of resources. Office hours and TA are incredibly helpful. The hw was also not too much and very helpful.

Weakness: I did often wish there was a sort of textbook schedule to follow for class. I remember in Chinese they would tell you which pages to read and what to look at before class so that when you went to class you could learn the material better. That would have been helpful.
The class was lots of fun and I loved the different projects and units. It felt like the start was a bit slow but the pace quickly picked up. There were a fair number of vocab quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms for practicing with the professor and with out classmates was very helpful for practicing listening and talking.

breakout room works well
of  course it will never be as effective as in-person learning in my opinion
Breakout rooms were very helpful to practice listening and speaking.
I enjoyed the use of break out rooms, I think this really helped to engage students during this years online learning format.

I think the breakout rooms were pretty helpful and a good way to get us to practice with a partner. This succeeded.
Don't think there was very much that could be improved honestly.

I think this course was amazing in terms of adjusting to the pandemic learning experience. The balance of breakout rooms and lecture time was great and allowed for students to practice comfortably with their peers. Honestly this was one of the only classes where I felt like I actually got to know my classmates a bit. The projects and tests (or lack thereof) were also very manageable online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I definitely recommend taking this class with Professor Lim. He's so patient, understanding, and funny! Your Korean will improve very quickly.
Yes, it was not a very stressful class but still a great and comprehensive introduction to korean.
yes, I like the teacher

Yes!  If you want to learn Korean this class is an accessible way.  It is direct, and help is readily available. You can get what you want out of this class, whether it's a general overview of how to read Korean and some basic vocab, or a deeper understanding of the grammatical structures involved.  For the low level of workload in this class, so much can be gained.
Yes! If you have an interest in Korean culture, this course is a great introduction.
Yes, it's a great class for students looking to start a new language.

Yes, absolutely. The professor is incredible and goes to great lengths to ensure you learn and understand what you need to. It does require some personal initiative, however, as most language courses do.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in Korean! Good teaching staff and always there to guide you.

Yes, I'd recommend this course to anyone who's interested in Korean or just wants to do a language credit. It's a great language and the class itself is a lot of fun. I also think it's probably easier than other L1 languages at Yale in terms of the workload.
